channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19 update 25 April: Five new cases, one death
item.description: Today there are five new cases of Covid-19 and a woman in her 70s has died.

item.title: Covid-19 liveblog: Latest news from NZ and around the world
item.description: One third of early childhood centres say they will remain closed in level 3, while 55 percent plan to open, the Early Childhood Council says.

item.title: Wellington eatery showcase to launch Monday
item.description: A new digital hub showcasing Wellington eateries has been created, with all businesses that sign up eligible to receive a subsidy of up to $500.

item.title: Young Labour camp offender to keep fighting for name suppression
item.description: The man who admitted assaulting two teenage boys at a Young Labour summer camp is set to take his fight for name suppression to the Court of Appeal.

item.title: Nearly 80 percent of Māori military personnel have PTSD symptoms
item.description: A study on serving or retired NZ military personnel has revealed alarming rates of PTSD symptoms - including 78 percent of Māori assessed.

item.title: Govt announces $40m funding for mental health service
item.description: The government is funding the further roll out of free mental health and addiction services across the country.

item.title: Anzac Day 2020 recap: Stand at dawn
item.description: Across the country, people stood at their driveways this morning to commemorate Anzac Day with "individual acts of commemoration".

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 24 April
item.description: The last weekend in level 4 lockdown is here and NZers are looking to the future, with businesses getting ready to resume, and research on anti-viral drugs continuing.

item.title: Watch RNZ's livestream of Anzac Day commemorations
item.description: RNZ has partnered with the RSA and the NZDF to broadcast a special Dawn Service - you can watch it here.

item.title: Kiwis commemorate Anzac day under lockdown rules
item.description: New Zealanders are commemorating Anzac Day all around the country today, despite the impact of Covid-19.

item.title: Blended families describe how kids, relationships impacted by lockdown
item.description: Broken bubbles, breached family court orders and children who haven't seen their parents in weeks - that's life in lockdown for many families with shared childcare arrangements.

item.title: Covid-19: Whānau relying on hunting for food should have exemption - leaders
item.description: Māori leaders are backing calls for the government to lift the ban on hunting during alert level three, but only to whānau who rely on it to feed themselves.

item.title: Air NZ 777 fleet grounded for a year
item.description: Air New Zealand is grounding passenger flights on its Boeing 777 flights until April next year, as it plans for a slow gradual entry back into international travel.

item.title: China's wild meat clampdown affecting NZ venison exports
item.description: New Zealand venison farmers are being caught out by the Chinese government's moves to clamp down on the trade of wild meat.

item.title: Coast councils support legal challenge to wetland labels on Māori reserves
item.description: The West Coast Regional Council may challenge the legality of labelling Maori reserves as wetlands or significant natural areas.

item.title: Gisborne council heeds call for urgent rates relief
item.description: Gisborne households and businesses will face a smaller rates increase next year, with district councillors seeking to provide some financial relief for ratepayers amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Rotorua Lakes Council accused of 'no show' on SNAs
item.description: Farmers are "disappointed" after Rotorua Lakes Council didn't make its own submission on a policy they say could result in a six percent rates rise.

item.title: Rates drop likely for some Ōpōtiki property owners
item.description: Some of Ōpōtiki's rural ratepayers can look forward to a small drop, but town-dwellers may be in for a rise.
